content.description: Climb the right facing corner with a crack placing gear to a steep headwall. Climb the headwall past 2 bolts with big reach to a jug/flake. Pull onto the ledge and follow a seam up and left to a bolt anchor.
Crimpy face climbing that has several different ways it can be approached. Some of the clips are tough. Good rock quality. Pumpy! Crux is the hard to find crimps from the 4th to 6th bolt.
content.location: It is the bolted climbed that starts right in front of the tree that is approximately 25 left of a "cave". Lower off the anchors (rap rings).

climbs.name: Waiting for Magness
climbs.fa: Bob Ahearn, Jonathan Garlough, Chris Magness

content.description: Start off the right side of the large boulder. Step onto the face following black bolt hangers to a crack and face with huge holds up high. Mantle onto the ledge up top with a bolt anchor.
Climb the blocky well featured face between Storyland and Five Years with sparse gear to the anchor of Storyland.
The first route you come to when the approach trail hits the cliff. Climb well featured blocky rock past a bolt. Continue up the face with big holds placing gear to a bolt anchor.

Climb up the face passing bolts to gear placements in short cracks. Continue past more bolts and move left into a left facing corner near the top. Place gear and work up the arete/face to the bolt anchor.

Start off a large boulder. Climb past three bolts to a short crack (#1 Camelot). Pull onto a small ledge and continue straight up past 2 bolts. A .5 sized piece can be placed to protect the run to the bolt anchor on top. Climb the line of bolts just right of the large spruce tree next to the cliff.

Stick clip the first bolt. Start off the blocks on orange rock. Slap up the arete of the small corner and gain a jug at the third bolt. From here going left to the seam is 11a/b or 11b/c if you stay right. Good holds await at the lip above the bolt anchor.
Locate a finger crack on the right side of the cliff. A hard scary start leads up the overhanging crack. Pull over onto a steep slab and follow the crack to a bolt anchor on top.

Start on a block and step over a void to gain the face and first bolt. Climb the crux sequential sheer face and pull over a small roof. Move left to the arete and follow it to the top to a bolt anchor.
Good climbing up a slanting, discontinuous crack. Loose chunk occasionally, needs some cleaning as it does not see many ascents, but definitely is worth the climb.
content.location: Near the center of the cliff, starts on top of a small block that is just to the right of the big block.

content.description: Climb up some blocky stuff to a ramp, then perform a couple tricky moves up the ramp - this is the crux. Layback and jam to a couple good holds near the lip. Go out right onto the face and climb a line of cracks up to the top. Anchor off of a tree and either lower, rap, or walk off towards the left.    Top half of the route is a little dirty.
content.location: Obvious overhanging, right trending ramp with a crack above it about 60 feet from the end of the cliff.

content.description: Start under a large roof down low and stick clip a high first bolt at the lip of the roof. Tech your way to a jug/flake over the lip of the roof. A big crux reach gets you over the roof. Continue up the face past bolts to easier terrain and a bolt anchor at the top.

Hayabusa climbs the overhanging right facing corner on the left side of the cliff. Stick clip the first bolt and move up rails to gain the corner. Climb the face/corner past bolts with great movement and holds. It isn't over until you mantle into the alcove with a bolt anchor.

Start on the right edge of the cave in the middle of the cliff. Climb past 2 bolts to gain the roof. Follow the crack out the right side of the roof passing a spruce tree growing out of the crack. Continue up the crack to a bolt anchor on top.

Climb the face past a bolt to gain discontinuous cracks. Climb the cracks until they end and gain a bolt. Pull over a block/flake to a lower angled slab with a bolt out right. Finish up and left to the Storyland anchor.

Locate the large cave in the middle of the cliff. This route climbs in the back of the cave up blocky cracks to a roof. Pull out the roof using the left crack and gain a ledge. Follow the crack/seam straight up to a bolt anchor.

The first route on the steeper section of the cliff. Stick clip a low pin and the first bolt. Suspect holds down low lead you to a sheer face. The crux is getting the jug by the second bolt. Continue straight up on better holds into a fun stemming corner which brings you to a bolt anchor.

Located in the alcove on the far right side of the main cliff. Stick clip a high first bolt. Boulder up the overhanging face to a flake at half height. A big crux move up and left leads to an arete/corner. Follow this to the bolt anchor on top.

Climb up to a high first bolt. Continue up and slightly right following the line of bolts. Pull a small overlap and gain a ledge (optional .4 cam). A few moves gain a shared anchor with Pitch of Peace.

Start off the left side of a large Boulder. A low crux will feel in the 11a-11c range depending where you go. Continue up easier climbing above to a bolt anchor. Follow the line of bolts just left of a large spruce tree next to the cliff.

Climb past two bolts to an overhanging sheer face with vertical seams and crimps. A hard boulder problem gets you to the lip. Mantle onto a small ledge. Finish straight up past two more bolts on easier terrain to a bolt anchor.

This is a relatively new crag that is located in the hills of Jackson Village behind the Eagle Mountain House. A few trad routes were climbed in the late 90's by Jason Seaver & Todd Swinton, but the face routes were left untouched. In 2011 the crag was rediscovered and many new lines started to pop up. There is now over 20 established climbs! Some sport, some mixed, and some trad with a wide range of grades. The routes have been cleaned, but watch out for loose rock, things are still cleaning up. The cliff goes into the shade early and is nice on those hot sunny days. Eagle Mountain Cliff combined with Jackson Crag makes for a great weekends worth of climbing.  

  Check out the Eagle Mountain House for lodging. They also have a fun little bar and restaurant area for a convenient stop after a day of climbing!
